text: As a step toward elucidating the pathophysiological background of the so-called glucose toxicity to pancreatic beta cells , we induced glycation in HIT-T15 cells using a sugar with strong deoxidizing activity , D-ribose , and examined the effects on <extra_id_0> insulin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene transcription .

text: The results of reporter gene analyses revealed that the <extra_id_0> insulin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene promoter is more sensitive to glycation than the control <extra_id_0> beta-actin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene promoter ; approximately 50 and 80 % of the <extra_id_0> insulin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene promoter activity was lost when the cells were kept for 3 d in the presence of 40 and 60 mM D-ribose , respectively .

In agreement with this , decrease in the <extra_id_0> insulin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA and <extra_id_0> insulin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> content was observed in the glycation - induced cells .

text: Also , gel mobility shift analyses using specific antiserum revealed decrease in the DNA - binding activity of an <extra_id_0> insulin gene transcription factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> PDX-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> IPF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> STF-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

These effects of D-ribose seemed almost irreversible but could be prevented by addition of 1 mM aminoguanidine or 10 mM N - acetylcysteine , thus suggesting that glycation and reactive oxygen species , generated through the glycation reaction , serve as mediators of the phenomena .

text: These observations suggest that protein glycation in pancreatic beta cells , which occurs in vivo under chronic hyperglycemia , suppresses <extra_id_0> insulin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene transcription and thus can explain part of the beta cell glucose toxicity .
